Derek James wrote:

>>The problem with this of course is that we allow
>>large chromomses to 
>>have large differences and still be within the same
>>species. 
>>    
>>
>
>As long as it's proportional, I don't see the problem.
> Chromosomes that vary by %20, for example, no matter
>what size they are, would be placed in different
>species.  
>
>  
>
Ok now I've woken up a bit... yes I agree with you here. Although one 
point I would like to make is that this only works for direct encoding 
schemes, NEAT is ok because a NEAT chromosome is a direct encoding of a 
NN. If you start to consider indirect encoding (as in biology) then you 
find that small changes in the genetic make up can result in large 
changes in the phenotype. The solution is to compare phenotypes - which 
is something I didn't take into a account in my own code which IS does 
use indirect encoding.

>Yes, Ken talks about dynamic thresholding in the NEAT
>Users FAQ.  This seems like a reasonable approach, but
>leads to a couple of points.
>
>The philosophy behind speciation then shifts from:
>
>--species are subgroups that vary topologically by a
>particular amount
>
>to:
>
>--a species is not defined as much by topological
>difference as by the number of species threshold
>
>That is, in the second case, a given species could
>have much more or much less topological difference
>between its individuals.  This approach seems less
>desirable to me, since it seems less
>biologically-inspired.  You're enforcing an arbitrary
>division of the population, rather than defining
>species primarily by a distance function.
>
>  
>
Agreed.

>If you do use dynamic thresholding and define a set
>number of species, this approach then leads to the
>question: What is a good number of species for a
>population?
>
>  
>
>And should the number of species allowed then be
>proportional to the population size?  
>
>  
>
After reading this and having a think I do agree with you on this. So 
going back to your original email, it's interesting that Ken used a 
fixed N=1, or was this because the chromosome never became larger than 
20 in length? Either way the use of N=1 when size<20 seems like an 
unnatural step, perhaps we need an equation that increases the 
compatibility value for small chromosomes (as ken has done) but that 
doesn't have that unnatutal step at length=20.

Consider what happens when N becomes 20. Chromosomes that were 
previously in seperate species may now be classed as being in the same 
species, because although they have large values for D and E , these are 
reduced by the now large N=20. This sudden reclassification of all 
members in the population is surely a bad thing.

So we are being pulled by Ken's work on one hand - which works well but 
only covered the ground where length<20 and N=1. And on the other hand 
we want to go beyond length=20 (with normalization) but avoid the nasty 
step.

I should like to ask Ken if the his chromosomes actually approached a 
length of 20, since we can alleviate the problem by reducing the step 
point and/or having more than one step point. E.g.

for length<5,  N=1
for 5>=length<10,  N=5
for 10>=length<15, N=10
for 15>=length<20, N=15
for length>=20, N=length


Colin.
